awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Heavy Metal Survey: Stellar Metallicities and Chemical Abundance Patterns of Massive Galaxies out to z~2.3
awd_abstract_narration:
As galaxies grow and age, their chemical composition changes as a result of their own star formation as well as the history of any mergers that they may have had with other galaxies. At large distances, previous studies only measured the chemical composition of galaxies that were actively forming stars. This project will take advantage of new instruments available on the Keck telescope to measure the chemical composition of quiescent galaxies, which are more common than star-forming galaxies out to the distances accessible by these instruments. This data will then be used to provide information about the histories of distant quiescent galaxies.

The project will use the MOSFIRE and LRIS spectrographs on Keck to obtain a survey of the metallicities of 20 quiescent galaxies in a redshift range of 1.3-2.3. They have 16.5 nights scheduled on Keck for this survey. Upon completion of the analysis of the spectra, the team will use the chemical abundance patterns, structural parameters, and stellar abundance patterns from the survey data to constrain assembly histories and star formation histories of quiescent galaxies over cosmological timescales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project is to shed new light on the formation histories of massive galaxies by studying their chemical compositions. To achieve this goal, we executed the Heavy Metal survey, a 26 night program with LRIS and MOSFIRE on the Keck I Telescope targeting massive quiescent galaxies from a time when the universe was about 3 to 4.5 billion years old. We also made use of the public LEGA-C survey, which targetted similar galaxies from around 7 billion years ago, when the universe was half its current age. Both surveys provide the deepest ground-based spectroscopic observations available for their respective epochs, enabling robust measurements of spectral features originating from various chemical elements such as iron and magnesium. These elements, produced by different astrophysical events over varying timescales, provide unique insights into the timeline of a galaxy's formation.
This program was the first to reveal the chemical compositions of statistical samples of massive quiescent galaxies over the past 11 billion years. From these measurements, we reconstructed the star formation and stellar mass assebly histories of these galaxies. First, we showed that quiescent galaxies formed their stars in short vigorous starbursts that ended abruptly. This scenario aligns with the idea that supermassive black holes may play an important role in stopping the formation of new stars in massive galaxies. Second, we found that after galaxies stop forming stars, they continue to grow through mergers with other galaxies and possibly some late-time star formation. Third, we observed that more massive and denser quiescent galaxies are more metal-rich across all epochs, likely due to their large gravitational pulls that can more easily retain metals.
 
The ultra-deep Heavy Metal spectra also allowed us to measure the stellar motions in these distant quiescent galaxies, resulting in robust measurements of their total or dynamical masses. We found that these dynamical masses are in good agreement with the stellar masses, indicating that dark matter contributes minimally in the central regions of these galaxies. Additionally, we provided constraints on the initial mass function of stars, which details how many stars are born of a certain mass. Furthermore, two galaxies in our samples showed evidence for large amounts of outflowing gas, likely driven by their supermassive blackholes, further supporting the critical role of black holes in regulating star formation in galaxies. Finally, follow-up observations with ALMA allowed us to study the cold gas properties of the young quiescent galaxies. Interestingly, a systems of two neighbouring quiescent galaxies, likely in the process of colliding, still possessed a large gas reservoir. This finding provides further constraints on the physical mechanism responsible for halting the formation of new stars. 
In addition to advancing our understanding of galaxy evolution, our program has implications for other astrophysical fields. For example it sets new constraints on supernova yields and dark matter halo properties. Furthermore, our program has provided extensive training and mentoring opportunities for a diverse group of students. Four graduate students and two undergraduate students were involved in various aspects of the programs, gaining hands-on experience in observing with MOSFIRE and LRIS, analyzing spectroscopic data, and leading scientific projects based on the data. Additionally, we have delivered several public talks about our program and maintain a public webpage with information about our survey. We have also shared our MOSFIRE reduction software with numerous other teams, thereby supporting many other projects.
